'''Little Sonny Jones''' (April 15, 1931 – December 17, 1989) was an [[United States|American]] [[New Orleans blues]] singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=little-sonny-jones-p141666/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Little Sonny Jones  |author=Bill Dahl |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 24, 2011}}</ref> Over his lengthy career, Jones worked with various blues [[musician]]s, most notably [[Fats Domino]].

He is not to be confused with fellow blues musicians, [[Little Sonny]] nor [[Little Sonny Warner]].

==Biography==
He was born '''Johnny Jones''' in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]], and started singing professionally in the late 1940s.  He befriended [[Fats Domino]] and, whilst working together, was given his [[nickname]] by Domino. In 1953 he released his debut [[Single (music)|single]], "Do You Really Love Me" / "Is Everything Allright?", on [[Specialty Records|Specialty]].  Jones recorded a further four songs for [[Imperial Records|Imperial]] in 1954, which were produced by [[Dave Bartholomew]], but all releases failed to find a commercial market.  His connection with Domino endured and, up to 1961, Jones remained as Domino's opening act.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= Rick
| last= Coleman
| year= 2006
| title= Blue Monday: Fats Domino and the Lost Dawn of Rock 'n' Roll
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Da Capo Press
| location= [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]
| isbn= 0-306-81531-1
| page= 69}}</ref> Jones tracks included the [[blues standard]], "[[Farther Up the Road]]".

Jones was employed as the vocalist by a New Orleans based band led by the brothers, David and Melvin Lastie, until the late 1960s.<ref name="AMG"/> Jones also had regular employment at a sugar factory.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Edward
| last= Amos
| year= 2002
| title= Gravesites of Southern musicians
| edition= 1st
| publisher= McFarland Press
| location= United States
| isbn= 0-7864-1270-4
| page= 17}}</ref> He returned to the [[recording studio]] in 1975, and issued his [[album]], ''New Orleans R&B Gems'', initially on the [[Netherlands]] based Black Magic [[record label|label]].<ref name="AMG"/> With contributions from veteran musicians including Dave "Fat Man" Williams, the [[Gramophone record|record]] faithfully copied the [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] style and sound of the 1950s. It was re-issued in 1995 by [[Black Top Records|Black Top]].<ref name="Album"/>

Jones was a regular performer at the [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In December 1989, Jones died of [[heart failure]] in New Orleans, at the age of 58.<ref name="AMG"/>
